conversations.content: Flamewyrm and Butterfly: Part One
The Flamewyrm's earliest memory was of a tiny butterfly alighting on the tip of her snout after she descended the volcano as a hatchling.
＂Who are you?＂ asked the curious Flamewyrm.  ＂I am Butterfly,＂ answered the tiny creature.
The Flamewyrm believed she and this small insect were two of a kind, as they both bore wings of brightest red.
They spent a summer of laughter and joy together, but as autumn's chill crept across the land, it came time for Butterfly to depart.
The aged butterfly lay on the tip of the Flamewyrm's snout, and said in a small, weak voice, ＂I'm afraid my life is at its end.＂
＂No!＂ cried the Flamewyrm. ＂Our friendship is still young, and already we must say good-bye?＂  ＂No,＂ replied Butterfly. ＂Not 'already.'＂
＂Our lifetimes have a different worth. I have lived, had children, and grown old—while to you, but an instant has passed.＂
＂You aren't like me,＂ said Butterfly. ＂You are far, far more special.＂ And with that, she moved no more.
For centuries, the Flamewyrm lay dormant in the fields, dreaming of her time with Butterfly. Then humans came and rent the fields asunder.
Enraged, the Flamewyrm set the human colony ablaze and left to make a home for herself elsewhere.
In their terror, the humans began referring to her as the Wrathwyrm. But the Flamewyrm paid them no mind.
Humans pay no heed to short-lived insects, after all. And if life span determines worth, what reason have dragons to value humans?
＂I am more magnificent than any other being,＂ mused the Flamewyrm. ＂That is why I live the longest.＂
But that thought brought her no joy. She would have rather lived as the tiny butterfly.
If only it could have been so...
Flamewyrm and Butterfly: Part Two
The Flamewyrm again shut herself away in a volcano that none dared approach. She had no visitors, but also avoided her hated farewells.
The years passed in solitude, and the Flamewyrm's memories of her friend faded until they seemed only a distant dream—which was exactly how she wished it to be.
Ages elapsed, and the shape of the land itself shifted. There seemed no creature of merit to the immortal Flamewyrm.
But one day, her ears perked to whispers of a human king, Alberius,  to whom ancient dragons had been swearing allegiance.
The Flamewyrm traveled to the Windwyrm's nest. ＂Why aid them?＂ she asked. ＂It is foolishness! All they do is scrabble about and then perish. They are nothing like us!＂
The Windwyrm smiled. ＂That is for the best. Short-lived they may be, but they leave their mark upon the world. They are...beautiful.＂
At this the Flamewyrm scoffed, though she was beset with thoughts of the small butterfly she befriended all those many years ago.
The sight of her fluttering through the air truly WAS beautiful...
Rearing her head, the Flamewyrm saw a swarm of butterflies in the field, frolicking on red wings identical to those of her long-gone friend.
At this, she suddenly wondered if her friend had left a mark upon the world after all. For it seemed her life—and those of all creatures—wove together over time to form a greater tapestry.
Perhaps small creatures were just as deserving of the respect they showed to those larger than themselves.
＂Preposterous,＂ thought the stubborn dragon. ＂We are the superior beings.＂
It would be some time until the Flamewyrm came around. Not, in fact, until she met a certain prince...
